b9e3e51f-dd95-4673-97e5-55baf7947fe8.description: Earners of the Rajasthan Royals Sports Marketing Foundation badge have gained insights into the way sports are organised, the fundamentals of marketing principles, how these are applied in sports marketing and the digital trends and platforms that sports marketers are utilising today. This course is offered in partnership with Deakin University.
b9e3e51f-dd95-4673-97e5-55baf7947fe8.name: Rajasthan Royals Sports Marketing Foundation

badge_template_activities.title: The course material integrates Rajasthan Royal video insights which are specially created videos by the marketing and business professionals at the club that bring the theory to life with real stories of sports marketing in action. To complete the course, earners completed four learning modules of the short course which includes a mix of theory and practice examples:

Module 1: Sport organisation. Earners got the opportunity to learn how to define sport in relation to sport management, identify agencies responsible for the organisation of sport internationally and locally, describe the governance, management and policy practices of sport organisations, and understand the role of corporate sport and events.

Module 2: Marketing fundamentals. Earners got the opportunity to learn how to describe the principles and practices of marketing management and research as they apply to the unique characteristics of sport and sport management, explain the relevance of the marketing function and its place in the role of management, and also gain insight into the 4P’s of marketing and the need for ROI (return on investment).

Module 3: Sports Marketing. Earners got the opportunity to learn how to describe marketing concepts and recognize their application within real-world scenarios, distinguish market information to develop segmentation, targeting and positioning strategies within culturally diverse environments, and recognise marketing strategies in different environments and contexts.

Module 4: Digital Trends and Platforms. Earners got the opportunity to gain insights into emerging trends in marketing, personalisation and technology, they also explored different digital platforms used to delivering marketing campaigns, and the role of social media in the marketing mix.

alignments.name: Deakin Credentials Levels Standard
alignments.description: Deakin's credential levels are aligned with global academic and industry standards. The credential awarded provides formal recognition and validation of demonstrated capabilities in the workplace. To learn more about Deakin's credential levels, please click the link.

badge_template_activities.title: This credential is verified by Deakin University.
Credential submissions are assessed by academic and industry practitioners with relevant experience.

The submission process is evidence based and successful achievement of a credential requires a portfolio of evidence, a written reflection and a video testimony showcasing the relevant skills and knowledge at the expected level. The submission has addressed and demonstrated all criteria listed below:
Promotes a culture that encourages and enables effective communication.
Communicates with meaning to positively inform or influence specialist and non-specialist groups and diverse stakeholders.
Represents the organisation with authority and credibility beyond the business area, externally, or publicly.
Prepares and presents articulate and influential, reports, documentation and presentations.
Gives and receives clear instructions or recommendations on often very complex and conceptually ambiguous topics or strategic issues.

dfb09e36-5e53-4c0f-9921-dba0727d7e3a.description: The Global Citizenship Award recognises the achievement of students who have demonstrated outstanding global citizenship through engagement in a range of activities that develop and demonstrate their interpersonal and intercultural capability across variable cultural contexts and global environments. This award recognises the importance of intercultural understanding and respect to the success of graduates, organisations and communities.
dfb09e36-5e53-4c0f-9921-dba0727d7e3a.name: Global Citizenship Award

badge_template_activities.title: To receive the Global Citizenship award students need to engage in a range of international activities that develop and demonstrate the following capabilities:
Interpersonal and intercultural capability, including demonstration of independence and ability to manage adversity.
Disciplinary awareness across variable cultural contexts and challenging global environments.
Ability to operate within a professional and globalised work environment, including networking and organisation management skills.
The standards for this award were developed by a cross-disciplinary team at Deakin in consultation with representatives from Mitsui & Co. (Australia) Limited.

58ebdc1d-0dd2-41bc-a464-b30da28fcb43.description: Earners of the Rajasthan Royals Sports Marketing Advanced badge have gained insights into the role of sport in society, the practical delivery of sports marketing, sports governance and leadership, and how the fan experience is created. They have also gained ‘real world’ practical insights into a year in the IPL. This course is offered in partnership with Deakin University.
58ebdc1d-0dd2-41bc-a464-b30da28fcb43.name: Rajasthan Royals Sports Marketing Advanced

badge_template_activities.title: The course material integrates Rajasthan Royal video insights which are specially created videos by the marketing and business professionals at the club that bring the theory to life with real stories of sports marketing in action. To complete the course, earners completed five learning modules of the short course which includes a mix of theory and practice examples:

Module 1: Sport in society. Eaners got the opportunity to learn about the history of sports and how this evolved to where sport is today, critically analyse organised sport in a variety of cultural contexts, and interpret key issues and problems in international sport, considering the implications of such an examination for the modern-day sport manager and administrator.

Module 2: Sports Marketing. Eaners got the opportunity to gain insights into the the fundamentals of marketing and the creativity involved in creating a marketable product, synthesise the principles of marketing management and frameworks used, interpret market factors and develop strategic marketing approaches around the Product Lifecycle (PLC), and consider sponsorship and new media possibilities.

Module 3: Sports Leadership and Governance. Eaners got the opportunity to judge governance, policy, power, and ethical practice in contemporary sport organisations, interpret the multiple roles and functions of a board in the strategic leadership of sport organisations, and understand some of the ethics issues in sport.

Module 4: Creating the Fan Experience. Eaners got the opportunity to understand why customer experience is important for the fans of sport, what are the consumer trends impacting marketing , and consider the elements for building a marketing campaign.

Module 5: Rajasthan Royals Master Class. Earners got the opportunity to participate in an immersive masterclass that provides indepth and unique 'behind the scenes' insights into what a year in Sports Marketing actually entails within a global sporting franchise, and reflect on the theory presented through the course, while experts in their respective fields explain its practical application in the commercial world.

badge_template_activities.title: This credential is verified by Deakin University.
Credential submissions are assessed by academic and industry practitioners with relevant experience.

The submission process is evidence based and successful achievement of a credential requires a portfolio of evidence, a written reflection and a video testimony showcasing the relevant skills and knowledge at the expected level. The submission has addressed and demonstrated all criteria listed below:
Isolates the factors that drive personal and professional conduct.
Identifies and effectively addresses ethical dilemmas, conflicts of interest or where work practice may deviate from ethical standards.

Promotes a culture of professionalism and integrity in all interactions with stakeholders e.g. colleagues, customers, business partners or the community.

2be71862-3ff6-4830-a793-f5b6707e4ced.description: Earners of the Rajasthan Royals Sports Media and Broadcasting badge have gained insights into the sports media industry, the art of sports storytelling, the commercialisation of sport, sports media ethics and culture, and the various media platforms available today and potential future trends. They have also gained practical insights into what a career in sports media entails from an acclaimed international sports journalist. This course is offered in partnership with Deakin University.
2be71862-3ff6-4830-a793-f5b6707e4ced.name: Rajasthan Royals Sports Media and Broadcasting

badge_template_activities.title: The course material integrates Rajasthan Royals video insights which are specially created videos by business professionals at the club and a leading sports journalist and presenter, Mayanti Langer Binny, that bring the theory to life with real stories of sports media and broadcasting. To complete the course, earners completed six learning modules that comprised a mix of theory and practical examples.

Module 1: The Sports Media Industry. Earners got the opportunity to learn about the dimensions of sports media and entertainment in the context of storytelling and societal impact, the different roles media companies take in producing sports, and to critically review sports media deals to assess the economic, fan and audience impacts.

Module 2: Sports Storytelling. Earners got the opportunity to learn about the production cycle for sports storytelling, the careers and roles involved in delivering sports broadcasts, critically review diversity issues and challenges in the sports media and broadcasting industries and understand how this is currently being addressed and review the role that technology has taken in advancing the entertainment value for sports audiences.

Module 3: Commercialising Sport. Earners got the opportunity to understand the relationship between sports bodies and broadcasters and why they are vital to each other, the role advertising plays in the success of broadcasting and streaming of sports events, and why some sporting leagues choose to manage their own broadcasts end-to–end via their own networks.

Module 4: Sports Media Ethics & Culture. Earners got the opportunity to learn how politics can intersect with sports and sporting events, why sports athletes have an additional responsibility as role models, and how social media impacts sports scandals and drug taking.

Module 5: Media Platforms. Earners got the opportunity to learn about the key platforms for media and broadcast and how they have evolved over recent decades, and to critically examine social media content and understand where it fits into the media ecosystem. Through a detailed case study, earners also got the opportunity to closely examine the Indian media market and how it has changed from a state broadcast system through to a diverse content creation ecosystem today.

Module 6: The Future of Sports Entertainment. Earners got the opportunity to review some of the potential new technology that could drive the future creation of sports entertainment, reflect on the global sports media and broadcast industry and consider how this may change over the coming decade, and learn from the career journey shared by a professional working in the sports media and broadcasting industry.

8f90eb75-3ad1-43d1-9ed2-378b2da85583.description: Earners of the Rajasthan Royals Sports Events and Facilities Management badge have gained insights into the global sports events industry, commercial models used within the industry, the evolution of modern sports stadiums, core operational functions of stadiums, and recent innovations in sports fan experience. Earners also gained insights from case studies in stadium development, stadium operations, and the Tokyo Olympics. This course is offered in partnership with Deakin University.
8f90eb75-3ad1-43d1-9ed2-378b2da85583.name: Rajasthan Royals Sports Events and Facilities Management

badge_template_activities.title: The course material integrates Rajasthan Royals video insights which are specially created videos by business professionals at the club, as well as a leading sports professional with extensive experience in managing global sports events. The course also presents a case study of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics being delivered against the backdrop of the Covid-19 pandemic. To complete the course, earners completed six learning modules that comprised a mix of theory and practical examples.

Module 1: The Sports Event Industry. Earners got the opportunity to review the historic growth of the diverse sports events industry we have today, understand the role of governing bodies and international sports organisations and the process of bidding for and delivering events, and the social and economic impacts of sporting events and the legacy they leave.

Module 2: Creating Compelling Events. Earners got the opportunity to learn financial approaches applied to prospective events to ensure viable commercial outcomes, the types of sponsorship partnerships in use within the industry, and the role volunteers play in event organisation and implementation.

Module 3: Sports Facility Operations. Earners got the opportunity to learn about the evolution of sports facilities through history, the financial streams available from the operation of sports facilities, and how stadiums and facilities are able to attract events through leveraging their market position.

Module 4: Facility Operations. Earners got the opportunity to learn how catering, ticket sales, hospitality, merchandising, and transportation are organised by a professional venue, review the security and safety elements along with the marketing and event attraction management, and the role that evolving technology has in providing connectivity for fans attending venues.

Module 5: Experience and Innovation. Earners got the opportunity to learn about the lifecycle of the fan experience and the focus sporting events and brands are putting on this, the economic and physical impacts of sports events and what legacy they can leave, the importance of sustainability and diversity in the context of events and facilities, and what the future may look like for the sporting industry.

Module 6: Sports Events and Facilities Masterclass. Earners got the opportunity to learn about the elements required to create a major sports event and consider what makes them unique, iconic and popular. Earners reflected on the range of professional sports facilities and the key operational imperatives required to run successful events. Earners reviewed case studies on the development and operation of several sports stadiums as well as the delivery of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

This microcredential provides the earner with bankable credit (0.5 credit points) towards one or more specified post graduate degrees (award course) at Deakin University. The credit is redeemed on successful application to study the degree.
Successfully completed this online course with learning activities and formal assessment typically requiring 50-75 hours.
LEARNING OUTCOMES:
Explain why present governance practices are failing and how governance differs from whole of organisation governance
Identify governance failures and set strategic objectives for your organisation, exploring collective wisdom, systems thinking and eco-systems
Consider independence and integration of governance practices, the role of principles in governance practices and the approach to risk and compliance management
Discuss embedding transparency, openness and accountability, and organisational capabilities

Explore what ‘Sustainable Leadership to 2030’ is and why it matters to business and your professional development

During their completed course they learnt to recognise, modify and manage emotions, and respond honestly and empathically to others. They have explored the factors that contribute to positive interactions and considered how to build trust and resolve issues and conflicts fairly and with compassion.

1d4ae4d8-4e27-4ff9-89c9-8d539ddf84be.description: Earners of this badge have explored how to lead and develop people to improve their organisational, engagement, skills, motivation and collaboration. They have learnt to work with team members so they are empowered to identify the resources and development opportunities they need to remain engaged and motivated. Participants also learnt how to share authority and responsibility, give constructive feedback and encourage the contribution of innovative ideas.
1d4ae4d8-4e27-4ff9-89c9-8d539ddf84be.name: DeakinCo. Short Course - Leading and Empowering Others - Practitioner

2b00c01f-37f7-4b46-a234-70d5ac09ce6e.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of students who have used their outstanding communication skills to explain an issue or innovation relevant to contemporary accounting practice in a cogent and engaging way to both accountants and non-accountants. This award recognises the essential role that communication plays in the employability of accountants, who need to communicate complex ideas to diverse stakeholders.
2b00c01f-37f7-4b46-a234-70d5ac09ce6e.name: Deakin Hallmark: Communication Excellence in Accounting

alignments.name: Identify and explain an issue or innovation relevant to contemporary accounting practice
Articulate and communicate relevant ideas in an appropriate, cogent, and engaging way to both accountants and non-accountants

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this Deakin Hallmark, students in the Bachelor of Commerce (Accounting) must write an article of publishable quality suitable for a diverse audience and pitch and defend the ideas conveyed in that article to a panel of experts.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of representatives from the course team and CPA Australia.
The criteria and standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed and endorsed by CPA Australia and EY Australia.

Assessment Panel: Dr Christine Contessotto (Director of Teaching , Accounting, Deakin University), Dr Sutha Kanapathippillai (Director of Bachelor of Commerce, Accounting, Deakin University), Sylvia Fryer (Education Manager, CPA Australia).

205edc90-4413-498f-b837-a7dbf0ff58f3.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of students who have demonstrated excellent communication skills and influenced others through their communication of health or science knowledge. This award recognises the importance of the ability to disseminate information, advice and opinion to the employability of biomedical science graduates who must communicate effectively with diverse people.
205edc90-4413-498f-b837-a7dbf0ff58f3.name: Deakin Hallmark: Communication Excellence in Biomedical Science

alignments.name: Ability to communicate effectively across diverse contexts
Leadership in the promotion of public health or science to influence or develop others

badge_template_activities.title: To achieve this Deakin Hallmark, students in the Bachelor of Biomedical Science must provide a narrated portfolio evidencing the impact of their advanced skills in communication and highlight key achievements to a panel of disciplinary experts through an oral presentation.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of disciplinary experts, including representatives from the course team, industry and a graduate of the course.

Criteria and standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed with and have been endorsed by:  A/Prof Caroline Owen, Head, Research Education, Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre;  Ms Joanne Mercuri, Lab Operations Manager Histology Australian Clinical Labs; Dr Shane Patella, Medical Manager and owner Pantheon Consulting; Mr Luke Terella, Consultant, Kudos Group Consulting; Mr Philip Leslie, GlaxoSmithKline; Dr Kirstie MacGill, Surgeon, Eastern Health, Royal Melbourne and Royal Children's Hospital.

7604452b-32db-4d76-9fa0-494e45b5d910.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of students who have used their outstanding communication skills to promote evidence-based nutritional science. This award recognises the essential role that communication plays in the employability of dietitians, who need to communicate complex nutritional science to clients, the community, health professionals and industry.
7604452b-32db-4d76-9fa0-494e45b5d910.name: Deakin Hallmark: Communication Excellence in Dietetics

alignments.name: Expertly demonstrates high level communication skills required to influence the health of a community or individual client
Proven ability to translate complex nutrition science information into language appropriate for a non-expert audience
Ability to build and strengthen relationships with key stakeholders

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this Deakin Hallmark, students in the Masters of Dietetics must collate a digital portfolio demonstrating evidence of their outstanding communication skills.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of disciplinary experts including representatives from the course team and health professionals from partner organisations.

The Criteria and Standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed with and have been endorsed by representatives from Austin Health, Epworth Healthcare, Nestle Health Science, Goulbourn Valley Health, Leading Nutrition, Latrobe Regional Hospital, Northern Health, Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre and Each - Community.

f53b40ab-0a99-4b20-9319-df2c2a76de0a.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of students who have demonstrated outstanding global citizenship in a business management context. This award recognises the importance of intercultural understanding and respect to the employability of business executives who must work effectively with people from diverse communities and cultures in an increasingly globalised business environment.
f53b40ab-0a99-4b20-9319-df2c2a76de0a.name: Deakin Hallmark: Global Citizenship Excellence in Business Administration

alignments.name: Advanced understanding and respect for diverse perspectives within a business management context
Proven ability to advance the intercultural competence of organisations through the application of management strategies and concepts

badge_template_activities.title: To achieve this Deakin Hallmark, students in the Master of Business Administration must provide a curated portfolio evidencing their advanced understanding of global perspectives and the impact of their strategic management on the intercultural competence of organisations or communities.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of disciplinary experts, including representatives from the course team, the Australian Institute of Management (AIM) and a graduate of the course.
The Criteria and Standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed and endorsed by the Australian Institute of Management (AIM).

Assessment Panel: Associate Professor Colin Higgins, (MBA Director, Faculty of Business and Law, Deakin University), Mr Kane Hooper, (MBA Graduate),  Ms Noel Waite, Australian Institute of Management (AIM), Ms Carmel McDonald, Australian Institute of Management (AIM).

55991411-bbfd-4e71-b4ae-df85bdeb9960.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of students who have used outstanding problem solving skills to evaluate, synthesise, and prioritise information to formulate a case management plan for a fictitious client, in keeping with core client-centred and family-centred practice principals. The case management plan involved the prioritisation of client goals, identification of barriers, and strategic utilisation of team and community resources to support achievement of the client’s goals.
55991411-bbfd-4e71-b4ae-df85bdeb9960.name: Deakin Hallmark: Problem Solving Excellence in a Health Professional Context

alignments.name: Outstanding assessment and response to a complex case-management problem
Ability to effectively communicate and justify solutions to key stakeholders
Ability to transfer and apply problem solving skills across different contexts

badge_template_activities.title: To achieve this Deakin Hallmark, students in the Bachelor of Psychological Science must learn the principles of case management, prepare a care plan using provided case notes, and defend the plan (and the problem-solving behind the plan), to a panel of disciplinary experts, including representatives of the course team and Department of Health and Human Services.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of disciplinary experts, including representatives from the course team and Department of Health and Human Services.
The criteria and standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed in collaboration with and endorsed by the Office of Professional Practice, Department of Health and Human Services.

Assessment Panel: Dr Melissa O’Shea (Associate Professor of Clinical Psychology, Director of Clinical and Community Partnership, School of Psychology, Deakin University),
Dr Lynne Webber (Principal practice leader, Research and Service Development, Office of Professional Practice, Department of Health and Human Services),
Dr Merrilyn Hooley (Senior Lecturer, Course Director Bachelor Psychological Science, School of Psychology, Deakin University).

6d2334b1-3336-49a6-9ebf-13c8aa8412da.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of preservice teachers who have used their outstanding teamwork skills to effect positive educational impact. The award recognises the essential role that teamwork plays in the employability of educators who must work and learn collaboratively with diverse groups of students, parents or carers, and colleagues, to design and deliver curriculum that engages students in meaningful learning.
6d2334b1-3336-49a6-9ebf-13c8aa8412da.name: Deakin Hallmark: Teamwork Excellence for Educational Impact

alignments.name: Demonstrates exemplary and sustained organisational and communication skills in team environments, including the ability to positively address challenges or mediate differing perspectives
Demonstrates a disposition for a life of learning that will improve student learning through transformed teaching team practices or team approaches

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this Deakin Hallmark, students undertaking initial teacher education courses at Deakin University must submit a digital artefact that provides compelling evidence of the Hallmark standards and criteria.

Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of experts within the education sector, including representatives from course teams, sector employers and professional partners (e.g. principals, teachers, site directors, recent graduates).
The Criteria and Standards for this Deakin Hallmark are endorsed by the Victorian Institute of Teaching.

The standards were developed in consultation with representatives from diverse areas of the Teaching Profession, including: the Victorian Institute of Teaching, Deakin & Community Childcare Centre, Leopold Primary School, Newcomb Secondary School, Woorana Park Primary School, Australian Institute of Teaching and School Leadership, Mooroolbark Deakin Alliance, Deakin preservice teachers and graduates, Deakin Institute of Koorie Education, Deakin Library and Deakin School of Education.

Assessment Panel: Ms Ann Stratford (Principal, Mooroolbark College); Ms Joanne Henriksen (Site Director, Northern Bay Alliance); Ms Amanda Peters (Site Director, Mooroolbark Alliance); Ms Jess Orr (Site Director, Ringwood Alliance); Dr Robin Bellingham (Master of Teaching Course Director nominee, Deakin University)

Assessment Panel, continued: Dr Francesca Bussey (Lecturer, Deakin Learning Futures, Deakin University); Associate Professor Josephine Lang (Associate Head of School, Teaching and Learning, School of Education Deakin University)

207821aa-8e3d-4302-a2ed-c6d7c8d7229b.description: This Deakin Hallmark recognises students with outstanding teamwork skills who have used those skills to make a substantial contribution to the field of Environmental Management and Sustainability. This award recognizes the importance of teamwork to the employability of environmental managers and sustainability practitioners who must work effectively with diverse stakeholder groups to address complex issues and produce positive outcomes for the environment and communities.
207821aa-8e3d-4302-a2ed-c6d7c8d7229b.name: Deakin Hallmark: Teamwork Excellence in Environmental Management and Sustainability

alignments.name: Sustained and meaningful contribution to diverse teams
Significant impact of teamwork on the field of environmental management and sustainability (within and beyond the course requirements)
Development or implementation of creative and innovative ideas or processes within a team

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this award, students in the Bachelor of Environmental Science (Environmental Management and Sustainability) must submit a digital portfolio and narrative that provide compelling evidence of having met the Hallmark standards.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of disciplinary experts, including representatives from the course team, industry and a past graduate of the course.

The concept for this Deakin Hallmark was endorsed by the Deakin University Environmental Sciences Advisory Board with members representing the following organisations:  Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (Victoria), Eastern Alliance for Sustainable Learning Parks Victoria Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources (South Australia), APA Group and Manningham City Council.

Assessment Panel: Dr Kelly Miller (Course Director, Deakin University), Prof Jan West (Associate Head of School of Life and Environmental Sciences, Deakin University),  Dr Kimberley James (Senior Lecturer, Deakin University), Ms Sarah Nickels (Eastern Alliance for Sustainable Learning Coordinator, Yarra Ranges Council), Mr Jack Krohn (Senior Impact Assessor, Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning), Mr Nicholas O’Brien (Graduate of the course).

This earner’s identification was verified using Jumio, automated online ID verification.
The earner passed a formal assessment submitting 2500-word reflective essay on their personal experience of change within the context of organisational innovation.

This microcredential provides the earner with bankable credit (0.5 credit points) towards one or more specified post graduate degrees (award course) at Deakin University. The credit is redeemed on successful application to study the degree.
Successfully completed this online course with learning activities and formal assessment typically requiring 50-75 hours.
LEARNING OUTCOMES:
Describe the drivers and potential barriers for internal innovation (intrapreneurship)
Reflect on and appraise your personal experience of change to formulate strategies for leading organisational intrapreneurship

Earners use different approaches to measure the customer’s experience, satisfaction and loyalty. They advocate honestly for the customer and the problems they encounter.

Earners of this badge completed a process of self-reflection to understand and modify their own actions in the workplace.

The submission process is evidence based and successful achievement of a credential requires a portfolio of evidence, a written reflection and a video testimony showcasing the relevant skills and knowledge at the expected level. The submission has addressed and demonstrated all criteria listed below:
Develops analytic plans for complex business challenges
Uses and provides guidance to others on a broad range of analytic techniques and technologies to create and improve analytics and models
Identifies relevant data sources required to address business challenges and projects
Reviews and makes sense of large volumes of complex or unstructured data to make recommendations
Informs and upholds organisational data management processes, methods and governance standards
Ensures accuracy and validity in data analysis, reporting insights and recommendations.

8a05e296-e411-47c3-9e0f-520ddb8acb26.description: Earners of this badge have gained insights into promoting and leading business intelligence activities within their organisation. They have looked at planning and defining business intelligence activities, within agreed architecture and data management solutions. They have learnt how to improve their strategy or business model and to develop standards and guidelines for business intelligence operations.
8a05e296-e411-47c3-9e0f-520ddb8acb26.name: DeakinCo. Short Course - Business Intelligence - Expert

d5009823-d25b-438d-ba74-871fd6be1f0d.description: Earners of this badge have learnt how to use the right tools and techniques to derive business insights from data and make effective business recommendations. This course they have completed covered the principles of business intelligence, defining the requirements for a business intelligence activity, and evaluating the validity and quality of data. They have also learnt to visualise and present data, and about the governance and ethics of data management.

They have explored ways to engage with and positively influence stakeholders relevant to operational outcomes. They were taught different approaches to measuring customer experience, satisfaction and loyalty.

8c345040-79f4-47f2-bafa-55808f7a9c64.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of students who have used their outstanding communication skills to identify and articulate ideas of relevance to contemporary arts and cultural management. This award recognises the essential role that communication plays in the employability of arts management graduates. Employment in the arts and cultural sector is highly competitive and demonstrably excellent skills in communication are key to finding success in the industry.
8c345040-79f4-47f2-bafa-55808f7a9c64.name: Deakin Hallmark: Communication Excellence in Arts and Cultural Management

alignments.name: Outstanding ability to identify and articulate ideas of relevance to contemporary arts and cultural management

Outstanding skills in written, verbal and interpersonal communication to diverse audiences including an advanced ability to contribute to public discussion about issues key to the arts and cultural sector
Proven ability to meet the standards of communication required by an external publishing platform

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this Deakin Hallmark, students in the Master or Graduate Diploma of Arts and Cultural Management must write and negotiate publication of an article on a recognised arts industry platform, and then pitch and defend the ideas conveyed in that article to a panel of experts including representatives from the course team and industry leaders.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of experts including representatives from the course team and industry leaders.

The Criteria and Standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed and endorsed in consultation with leaders from across the arts and cultural sector including representatives from: Arts Centre Melbourne, Theatre Network Australia, City of Melbourne, Melbourne International Comedy Festival, Geelong Performing Arts Centre, Millmaine Entertainment, Creative Victoria, Craft VIC, Newsboys Foundation, Queensland Performing Arts Centre, Cultural Development Network, Auckland Live and Geelong Gallery.

Assessment Panel (Deakin University): Dr Hilary Glow (Course Director, Arts and Cultural Management),
Anne Kershaw (Lecturer, Arts and Cultural Management Program), Prof Amanda Pyman (Head of Department of Management, Faculty Business & Law).

Assessment Panel (Partner Organisations): Jill Smith (General Manager, Geelong Performing Arts Centre); Nicole Beyer (Director, Theatre Network Australia)
Lisa Ferguson (Managing Director, Millmaine Entertainment), Damien Hodgkinson (Executive Director, Melbourne International Comedy Festival),
Kirsten Siddle (Associate Director, Queensland Performing Arts Centre), Simone Schinkel (Business development Manager, KAGE Physical Theatre).

faf26beb-68f6-4722-b266-64d2db9629ef.description: This Deakin Hallmark recognises students who have demonstrated exceptional achievements in entrepreneurial thinking, including having demonstrated the capacity to create value for themselves or others through the commercialisation of an idea. This award recognises that entrepreneurial thinking is important to the competitiveness of organisations in our globalised and face-paced economy.
faf26beb-68f6-4722-b266-64d2db9629ef.name: Deakin Hallmark: Excellence in Entrepreneurial Thinking

alignments.name: Demonstrates ability for advanced entrepreneurial thinking
Evidences capacity to create commercial value through the execution of an idea

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this Deakin Hallmark, Deakin students must submit a digital portfolio, written reflection and video pitch that provide compelling evidence of having met the Hallmark standards.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of experts including representatives from Deakin’s entrepreneurial ecosystem and other experienced entrepreneurs.

The Criteria and Standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed with and have been endorsed by representatives from Cyrise, Muru-D, EduGrowth, Tali Health, Moxie Reader, Geelong Chamber of Commerce, Techstars, Dimension Data, Startmate and Amazon Web Services, SPARK Deakin and ManuFutures.

Assessment Panel: Dr Heather Round (Senior Lecturer, Department of Management, Deakin University), Jason Steinwedel (Director, ManuFutures, Deakin University), Scott Handsaker (CEO, CyRise Venture Accelerator), Tamir Levin (Strategy and Innovation, CTO Office, NTT Ltd).

2decb2dc-82e2-42d3-86db-ab3100e556d8.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of preservice teachers who have used their outstanding teamwork skills to effect positive educational impact. The award recognises the essential role that teamwork plays in the employability of educators who must work and learn collaboratively with diverse groups of students, parents or carers, and colleagues, to design and deliver curriculum that engages students in meaningful learning.
2decb2dc-82e2-42d3-86db-ab3100e556d8.name: Deakin Hallmark: Teamwork Excellence for Educational Impact

alignments.name: Demonstrates exemplary and sustained organisational and communication skills in team environments, including the ability to positively address challenges or mediate differing perspectives
Demonstrates a disposition for a life of learning that will improve student learning through transformed teaching team practices or team approaches

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this Deakin Hallmark, students undertaking initial teacher education courses at Deakin University must submit a digital artefact that provides compelling evidence of the Hallmark standards and criteria.

Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of experts within the education sector, including representatives from course teams, sector employers and professional partners (e.g. principals, teachers, site directors, recent graduates).
The Criteria and Standards for this Deakin Hallmark are endorsed by the Victorian Institute of Teaching.

The standards were developed in consultation with representatives from diverse areas of the Teaching Profession, including: the Victorian Institute of Teaching, Deakin & Community Childcare Centre, Leopold Primary School, Newcomb Secondary School, Woorana Park Primary School, Australian Institute of Teaching and School Leadership, Mooroolbark Deakin Alliance, Deakin preservice teachers and graduates, Deakin Institute of Koorie Education, Deakin Library and Deakin School of Education.

Assesment Panel: Ms Ann Stratford (Principal, Mooroolbark College VIC); Ms Amanda Peters (Site Director, Mooroolbark Alliance VIC), Dr Matthew Thomas (Master of Teaching (Secondary) Course Director, Deakin University), Associate Professor Josephine Lang (Associate Head of School, Teaching and Learning, School of Education Deakin University).

e2a9bcec-aeeb-4b40-beec-545f16f3ba84.description: This Deakin Hallmark warrants the achievement of students who have demonstrated outstanding teamwork skills and understanding of how they should be applied to the field of property and real estate. This award recognises the essential role that teamwork plays in the employability of property professionals, who work in a dynamic environment, and must engage with colleagues and clients from diverse backgrounds to protect and further the interests of stakeholder and community groups.
e2a9bcec-aeeb-4b40-beec-545f16f3ba84.name: Deakin Hallmark: Teamwork Excellence in Property and Real Estate

alignments.name: Sustained and meaningful contribution to diverse teams within and beyond the course requirements
Significant impact of teamwork within and beyond the course requirements
Capacity to apply teamwork processes effectively and creatively to property and real estate

badge_template_activities.title: To receive this Deakin Hallmark, students in the Bachelor of Property and Real Estate must submit a digital portfolio and narrative that provides compelling evidence of the Hallmark standards.
Achievement of the Hallmark was judged by a panel of disciplinary experts, including representatives from the course team and the Australian Property Institute.
The Criteria and Standards for this Deakin Hallmark were developed with and have been endorsed by the Australian Property Institute.

Assessment Panel: Dr Ameeta Jain (Course Director, Property and Real Estate Undergraduate Programs, Deakin University), Dr Leanne Ngo (Learning Innovations Team Lead, Deakin University), Ms Kym Squire (Business Manager, Elmstone Property Group & Deakin Alumni), Mr Stephen Andrew (FAPI, MRICS, API President, National Director, Valuations and Advisory – Retail, JLL).

1fcde728-8ba9-44c8-9b6d-b4722cc95d52.description: Earners of Rajasthan Royals Professional Certificate in Social Media Marketing have gained valuable knowledge and insights into the rapidly growing fields of sports marketing & social media marketing. They have also gained insights into the core drivers of events and facility business streams and how they operate in a local, national and global context. This course is offered in partnership with Deakin University and Digital Vidya.
1fcde728-8ba9-44c8-9b6d-b4722cc95d52.name: Rajasthan Royals Professional Certificate in Social Media Marketing

badge_template_activities.title: The course material integrates video-based learning content from industry experts, exclusive case studies by Rajasthan Royals management team, hands on exercises and doubt clearing sessions. To complete the course, earners completed four modules that comprised a mix of theory and masterclass and assignments.

Module 1: Introduction to the Course - Earners got the opportunity to be introduced to the Program & Certification by Deakin University, to the Sports Marketing Industry by Rajasthan Royals and to the Digital Marketing Landscape by Digital Vidya. They also learned about how to become an influencer and various aspects of content creation.

Module 2: Earners got the opportunity to learn about content planning, content categories, different content format for different platforms, Hootsuite, creation and building, aspects community management like establishing connects and getting followers, organising offline events and hashtag, Facebook events influencer marketing and chatbots like Messenger, Chatfuel and WhatsApp Business API

Module 3: Earners got the opportunity to learn about Social Media Dark Arts, Facebook Business Manager, Social Media Ads creation process • Campaign Objectives • Ad Targeting • Ad types and Best Practices, Boost post and Instagram ads and Templates and Scheduling

Module 4: Digital Sports Marketing - The Rajasthan Royals Way! Earners learned about Introduction to Sports Marketing • Masterclass: How is digital marketing different for a sports brand compared to others • How social media becomes the inside access to Royals for fans • Case Study Exercises • Masterclass: Secrets to becoming the most entertaining brand in the digital world • How does digital marketing add value to the overall Royal’s ecosystem beyond engaging the fanbase • Assignment

badge_template_activities.title: This credential is verified by Deakin University.
Credential submissions are assessed by academic and industry practitioners with relevant experience.

The submission process is evidence based and successful achievement of a credential requires a portfolio of evidence, a written reflection and a video testimony showcasing the relevant skills and knowledge at the expected level. The submission has addressed and demonstrated all criteria listed below:

Promotes a customer-centric culture and collaborates across the business to assure business-wide alignment and accountability for customer-centric outcomes being understood and delivered business-wide.
Develops a customer experience strategy and implementation mechanisms for the organisation or function.
Holds leadership accountable for delivering on customer experience initiatives.
Collaborates to design and implement ways of working consistently with a human-centred design approach for internal and external customers.

Oversees research and investigations into factors impacting the current and future customer experience and communicates these insights to influence strategic decision making and investment priorities.

cc8a1b56-3966-41ac-a3ce-d1b73d9d6272.description: Earners of this badge have completed four of the following six DeakinCo. short courses - Principles of financial literacy; Fundamentals of collaboration; Digital fundamentals in a connected world; Fundamentals of communication; Fundamentals of customer experience; Insights and trends in data-driven marketing.

badge_template_activities.title: If this earner elected to undertake the Fundamentals of Collaboration short course as part of their Professional Readiness Program, they have explored how to work cooperatively with others, and make a positive contribution to a group when working to agreed plans or priorities. The completed course covered how to collaborate when working with others to achieve allocated tasks to agreed requirements. This earner has learnt how to proactively help and support their colleagues to achieve team goals.

If this earner elected to undertake the Fundamentals of Communication short course as part of their Professional Readiness Program, they have explored interpersonal, business and informative communication. Studying practical modules, they have worked on their skills to consult, actively listen and give feedback. They have learnt about different writing styles for business, how to create writing guidelines for their business and using presentations, audio visual tools and information sourcing.

If this earner elected to undertake the Fundamentals of Customer Experience short course as part of their Professional Readiness Program, they have gained an insight into how to provide customers with a quality experience by focusing on their needs and requirements; as well as explored how to apply the latest organisational or industry tools and techniques to analyse, monitor and gain insights into the customer experience.

If this earner elected to undertake the Insights and Trends in Data-Driven Marketing short course as part of their Professional Readiness Program, they have strengthened their marketing skills, focussing on synthesizing data and drawing out insights. They have also been taught how to collect and report data on customer experience, brand, product or campaign performance; and are better positioned to assist in implementing marketing campaigns based on data.

If this earner elected to undertake the Digital Fundamentals in a Connected World short course as part of their Professional Readiness Program, they have explored the different digital platforms used daily to find, evaluate, use and communicate information.

If this earner elected to undertake the Principles of Financial Literacy short course as part of their Professional Readiness Program, they have built an understanding of the basic finance principles to monitor, control and budget income and expenses, including interest or charges. They have explored currency and transactions, managing money, financial goals and understanding financial information.

skills.name: Collaboration; Knowledge Sharing; Communication; Conflict Resolution

badge_template_activities.title: If this earner elected to undertake the From Logic to Critical Thinking short course as part of their Skill Enhancement Program, they have developed their critical thinking skills to evaluate information and make decisions. They have explored methodologies to investigate issues, how to apply logical thinking and draw conclusions, as well has how to challenge assumptions. They are able to implement known models, logical processes and common sense to improve insights in tackling business problems.

If this earner elected to undertake the Participating in the Digital Age short course as part of their Skill Enhancement Program, they have gained knowledge in the standard technologies required to explore, access, create, publish and share information. They have learnt how to collaborate and provide access to information through the use of digital tools, and also understand appropriate user policies to protect personal identity, privacy and rights in a safe and secure manner.

If this earner elected to undertake the Effective Team Collaboration short course as part of their Skill Enhancement Program, they know that teamwork is crucial to business success and have looked at the best ways to effectively collaborate with others. They have explored achieving team goals by sharing knowledge and ideas, as well as different communication styles, how to draw on team strengths and weaknesses, the different team development stages, and models for conflict-resolution.

If this earner elected to undertake the Developing Data Driven Marketing Campaigns short course as part of their Skill Enhancement Program, they know how to develop original insights from assessing data on customer trends across a range of customer markets and channels. They have been taught how to use data to build marketing campaigns and understand the role of data for reviewing and recommending action for ongoing campaigns.

If this earner elected to undertake the Managing Income and Expenditure short course as part of their Skill Enhancement Program, they have built an understanding of how to manage income and expenses. They can recognise different types of financial institutions as well as understand the role regulatory bodies play in the financial sector. They have developed their knowledge and understanding of financial strategies, where to seek financial information and the importance of budgeting.

If this earner elected to undertake the Fostering Innovation in your Team short course as part of their Skill Enhancement Program, they have developed their ability to foster innovative practices within their team. They have learnt how to initiate opportunities for innovation, and how to drive team and project initiatives by putting in place mechanisms for team members to collaboratively capture, refine and progress ideas and innovations.

skills.name: Collaboration; Knowledge Sharing; Communication; Conflict Resolution

badge_template_activities.title: This earner’s identification was verified using Jumio, automated online ID verification. During the course the earner was an enrolled Deakin University student with the rights, responsibilities, access to resources and scrutiny of academic integrity required by this educational institution.
The earner passed a formal assessment submitting a 2000-word research brief in their chosen research topic, answering questions using a research plan of approach.
Successfully completed this online course with learning activities and formal assessment typically requiring 50-75 hours.

This microcredential provides the earner with bankable credit (0.5 credit points) towards one or more specified post graduate degrees (award course) at Deakin University. The credit is redeemed on successful application to study the degree.
Learning outcomes:
Explore different communication modes relevant to conducting and disseminating research in practice
Design a research proposal ready for implementation
Explore qualitative and quantitative research methods, using portfolio activities to define a researchable problem
Identify ethical approaches to research

LEARNING OUTCOMES:

badge_template_activities.title: This credential is verified by Deakin University.
Credential submissions are assessed by academic and industry practitioners with relevant experience.

The submission process is evidence based and successful achievement of a credential requires a portfolio of evidence, a written reflection and a video testimony showcasing the relevant skills and knowledge at the expected level. The submission has addressed and demonstrated all criteria listed below:
Monitors and assesses factors impacting digital marketing (i.e. market dynamics, competitor actions, online sales, technology disruptions and business change).
Assesses analytics and contextual information relating to target audience needs to more effectively implement a digital marketing strategy.
Consults with stakeholders and analyses data and insights to accurately target digital media solutions.
Monitors and assures compliance of digital marketing activities with all relevant company policies, industry standards and regulatory requirements (e.g. the Australian Privacy Principles).
Reviews and makes recommendations for innovation opportunities for products and processes.
Assesses marketing technology platforms for business need.

Describe a range of strategic and ideation frameworks in the context of innovation
Apply design thinking methods to propose human-centred approaches to problem solving
Evaluate the merits of different ideation strategies within the context of organisational innovation

Prepare a written report for an organisation containing recommendations and strategies for managing and leading culturally diverse teams based on the real-world experiences of your peers, and yourself. Part A –two to three interviews with peers: create an interview protocol (5 – 10 questions) and conduct interviews AND Part B – written report: 2000 words plus text transcripts of interviews (generated from recording interviews).
Successfully completed this online course with learning activities and formal assessment typically requiring 50-75 hours.

This microcredential provides the earner with bankable credit (0.5 credit points) towards one or more specified post graduate degrees (award course) at Deakin University. The credit is redeemed on successful application to study the degree.
Learning outcomes:
Reflect on cultural diversity within your own organisation and how culture influences your own perspective
Investigate the opportunities and challenges of culturally diverse teams and how to work with these
Develop strategies to lead culturally diverse teams and multicultural team members

skills.name: • Understand cultural identity and teamwork impact
